R: @kennknowles

Instead of creating a new concept for Spark, we should consolidate and have one pipeline parameter that is shared between runners like Dataflow/Spark/Flink/... since this parameter being added seems very similar to `filesToStage` found here:
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/a6f460fe3b760aafbc748ae18956f0f2c1fedfad/runners/google-cloud-dataflow-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/dataflow/options/DataflowPipelineWorkerPoolOptions.java#L203
https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/724eda37ea1e54aac089d89c711ca3cee14a4603/runners/flink/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/flink/FlinkPipelineOptions.java#L47

If we don't consolidate then we should use the same parameter name and types so that users have an easier time migrating between different runners.

Hi Pablo, thank you for this change.  If possible, I would like to avoid adding code that depends on internal Dataflow worker details.  I suggest that for the reader whose byte count you would like to observe, you inherit from ObservableMixin (see apache_beam/coders/observable.py) and register an observer for your particular use case.
Agree with Luke. Using the filesToStage makes sense.

I made a small change to allow building with, but not using, the package. Tested by building with this package as a dependency, then reading and writing GCS without --awsRegion and without any valid AWS credentials present.
I understood what's going on with Jackson. Instead of downgrading, I will align the dependency version with jackson module (as runner API uses jackson 2.8.9). It's better for the users. Let me do it.
I rebased and fixed the dependencies (especially `jackson-module`). It should be OK now.
That's a great tip, Charles. I've incorporated it into the change.

(rebased)

@lukecwik @jbonofre Thank you for the review. 

Now I see that the suggestion seems to be valid. However I see two issues here from IOITs point of view:
- suppose I add the `detectClassPathResourcesToStage()` method to fill up the worker's classpath. Such method will be able to find only production code's classes, not test ones, right? This won't be useful when running IOITs - there are lots of test classes to be found too (E.g: [this](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/common/src/test/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/common/HashingFn.java) won't be picked up, because it's a purely test code). 
This is why I wanted to pass jars directly through a pipeline option: one shaded uber jar with production code, and the other with test code.
- In Flink and Dataflow options `filesToStage` are `JsonIgnore`'d. AFAIK this means that those can be set only programatically, not from a command line pipeline option (--filesToStage). This also blocks IOITs because there's no way to pass the test jar. 

A solution that i think _might_ work and be even better is to:
 - change the name to `filesToStage` - it fits well
 - not add the `@jsonIgnore` annotation to this pipelineOption so that we are able to append new jars (those jars that cannot be detected)
 - *always* _detectClassPathResourcesToStage()_ before starting the runner but merge returned list of paths to resources with jars that were passed through a pipeline option.

I think this way we will be able to automatically detect production code, and "append" test code using a pipeline option.

What do you think of that solution? Or maybe there's a simpler way to "autodetect" the test code?
retest this please
The last time I messed with RAT config, I thought I learned that it does read `.gitignore`. Did you check the RAT log?

What makes you think that the test jars won't be part of the classpath and hence be missing from `detectClassPathResourcesToStage()`?

Agree on getting rid of `@JsonIgnore` from `filesToStage`.

I don't think we should change the semantic meaning of `filesToStage`, I could see us adding another flag like `additionalFilesToStage` or something along those lines since that has been requested in the past as well.

The reason why its not working is that the DirectRunner doesn't serialize/deserialize PipelineOptions so the `@JsonIgnore` doesn't come into effect on the `getAwsCredentialsProvider`. This is where my comment about being able to serialize PipelineOptions with a few well known CredentialsProviders would allow us to ship this across to the worker on runners with remote execution like Dataflow/Spark/Flink/...

Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3344 for DirectRunner to serialize/deserialize PipelineOptions before execution.

I aligned the rat configuration in Maven and Gradle.

@kennknowles rat uses the `defaultExcludes`but it doesn't read `.gitignore`. That's why we have the "`.gitignore`" exclude in the main `pom.xml`.

This is first Hadoop HDFS releated PR. SmallITCluster configuration with scripts to spin up and teardown cluster. HDFS configuration provides functionality of hdfs datanode and namenode running on the same pod on kubernetes. There are several ports opened and briefly described in .yaml file. Useful one is namenode http port which will be available on loadbalancer-ip:50070.
Lot of debug info could be found on /usr/local/hadoop/logs/ directory of pod.

Examples commands could be found here:
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1NiGpwgGU2OcQwuxOZlul5hk8TtImz9BUqoNCu4IkYn0

Perfkit profile and LargeITCluster will be submited in next PRs once we agree that this approach for SmallITCluster is correct. @chamikaramj @jasonkuster could you take a look/forward to right reviewers?

No problem ! Team work ! Thanks for the review ! Just waiting green light from Jenkins before merging.
Maven build needs #4259 to work (fix javadoc on `fn-execution`) to pass.

What I mean is this:

```
$ mvn -Drat.skip=false apache-rat:check -X
...
[INFO] --- apache-rat-plugin:0.12:check (default-cli) @ beam-parent ---
...
[DEBUG] Adding plexus default exclusions...
[DEBUG] Adding SCM default exclusions...
[DEBUG] Adding exclusions often needed by Maven projects...
[DEBUG] Adding exclusions often needed by projects developed in Eclipse...
[DEBUG] Adding exclusions often needed by projects developed in IDEA...
[INFO] Will parse SCM ignores for exclusions...
[INFO] Parsing exclusions from /usr/local/google/home/klk/GitHub/apache/beam/.gitignore
[DEBUG] Added 
[DEBUG] Added .gradle/
[DEBUG] Added .gogradle/
[DEBUG] Added build/
[DEBUG] Added vendor/
[DEBUG] Added 
[DEBUG] Added bin/
[DEBUG] Added dependency-reduced-pom.xml
[DEBUG] Added target/
[DEBUG] Added 
[DEBUG] Added sdks/java/maven-archetypes/examples/src/main/resources/archetype-resources/src/
[DEBUG] Added sdks/java/maven-archetypes/examples-java8/src/main/resources/archetype-resources/src/
[DEBUG] Added 
...
```

In #4027 I added a bunch of exclusions to the `pom.xml` but they turned out to be redundant and the problem was something else IIRC.

There is a subtlety that I only just sorted out fully. The patterns in a `.gitignore` are resolved relative to the `.gitignore` but _also_ directories inherit the `.gitignore` from parent directories.

So when `.gitignore` contains `vendor/` this means that when `git` is working in `sdks/go` it will inherit the `vendor/` ignore pattern, and it will work. But when the working directory is the root, `sdks/go/vendor` is not ignored.

I think it is probably best to just have full patterns in `.gitignore`, too. It also supports the same `**/vendor/` syntax.
@kennknowles good point ! It means that we can update .gitignore with the correct patterns and then delegate to rat (both in Maven and Gradle). Let me try this. Thanks !

Follow this checklist to help us incorporate your contribution quickly and easily:

- [x] Make sure there is a JIRA issue filed for the change (usually before you start working on it). Trivial changes like typos do not require a JIRA issue. Your pull request should address just this issue, without pulling in other changes.
- [x]  Each commit in the pull request should have a meaningful subject line and body.
- [x]  Format the pull request title like [BEAM-XXX] Fixes bug in ApproximateQuantiles, where you replace BEAM-XXX with the appropriate JIRA issue.
- [x]  Write a pull request description that is detailed enough to understand what the pull request does, how, and why.
- [x]  Run mvn clean verify to make sure basic checks pass. A more thorough check will be performed on your pull request automatically.
- [x]  If this contribution is large, please file an Apache Individual Contributor License Agreement.
